data.title: Records of the week for Noel Edmonds
data.meta_description: On several occasions I have responded to people's queries about what radio was like back in the 70s.
data.text:
On several occasions I have responded to people's queries about what radio was like back in the 70s. There tends to be the view that Radio One was all cheesy pop hits and fantabulous DJs. Although there was an element of that of course, it is worth stressing that daytime programming went much further than that. As proof I have found a list I made of Noel Edmonds' breakfast show records of the week. Sorry for the length but I feel that it does give an idea of how Radio One was not quite the Top 30 radio that many people imagine. Indeed most of the items on this list were far removed from the glitter era. Occasionally a surprising choice went on to become a hit (thanks to the plays, no doubt) e.g. Gaudete Steeleye Span, but apart from the big names (Elton, Bowie,...) it is quite amazing how many radio hits only ever made it to the lower reaches of the charts, if even that. Interesting to note the repeated choices of Jim Croce, John Stewart, Paul Williams, McTell, Goodhand-Tait, ... all quality stuff in my opinion. This is the period 73-75. I have more if anyone is interested and was wondering whether anyone ever noted down J Walker's Records of the week from that era or indeed his Ones that got away (which regrettably were often the same...)

Sarstedt Brothers - Chinese Restaurant
